posts.name: Heet Patel
posts.cooked: Hey, I wanted to know what CAN wire other teams ran and where they were purchased? Also wanted to know if it is worth it to get stranded wire for it?

link_counts.title: Do We Have to Use Official "CAN" Labeled Wire for the CAN Bus?

posts.name: Leo
posts.cooked:
All three of these FRC companies sell good quality CAN wire. We personally use the CTRE wire because we wanted to buy a larger roll, but they are all about the same.

WCP (25 ft for $10 : $0.40 per foot)

WCP (25 ft for $10 : $0.40 per foot)

CTRE (100 ft for $38 : $0.38 per foot)

CTRE (100 ft for $38 : $0.38 per foot)

ThriftyBot (25 ft for $10 : $0.40 per foot)

ThriftyBot (25 ft for $10 : $0.40 per foot)

link_counts.title: QTY 1 - 25 feet - 22 AWG CAN Bus Wire

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
For any exposed CAN , I highly recommend the WCP -1153 jacketed variant.  Regular twisted 22AWG CAN is easily damaged, so the extra jacket layer makes a big difference in level of protection.  It’s twice the price ($20 for 25 ft) but if it saves you losing CAN when your mechanism takes a hit, worth it.

We still stock the regular twisted kind for use in areas where it’s well protected.

Instead of standard insulated wire, we used Tefzel -coated wire for CAN . It’s commonly used in motorsport and aerospace applications and is near bulletproof compared to FRC -specific COTS wiring.

We didn’t run any testing on it, but we had to get a new pair of wire strippers because the old pairs we had just wouldn’t cut. Flush cutters also have a hard time getting through the insulation. We had zero broken CAN wires this year as a result. I wouldn’t be surprised if you could hang a robot from a twisted pair of 22 AWG Tefzel wire.

Tefzel is slightly more expensive, but it’s a fair bit smaller and lighter than silicone or PVC coatings at the same gauge. We use prowireusa to source ours.

@Baby_Carrot should have more info than I do, he’s our wiring/electronics lead.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Heet:

worth it to get stranded wire

There’s no place for solid wire in frc, unless it’s a jumper on a PCB or something similar.  You generally want finer/more stands anytime there’s a choice – and ferrules.

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked: We use 22 AWG yellow, 22 AWG green, with a freshman minion holding one end of the pair and a cordless drill on the other. The wire is 19 strand XLPVC insulated (UL 1430).

posts.name: Heet Patel
posts.cooked: Hey, do you think it makes a difference to get shielded can?

posts.name: Gus B
posts.cooked: As long as your CAN wire is twisted, you should be alright. As for recommendations, 1706 uses silicone wire, I believe it’s from TTB

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
Heet:

do you think it makes a difference to get shielded can?

No, shielding should not be necessary. CAN is designed to run over a twisted pair; the twist helps cancel out sources of electromagnetic interference, like the magnetic fields created by motors.  So it is important to use twisted wires and not untwist any more than necessary when making connections to devices.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
For the purists you want to braid not twist. Our electrical engineer mentor made a simple tool from two sticks and for those coming up from the Lego League a braiding machine . Lots of simple tools shown on the Internet and most demos show unnecessarily too tight of winding - too many rotations per distance.

The signal wants to follow a conductor that has a twist rate that the signal is going at so try to have a uniform rotations per distance.

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked: We stop at a twist per inch. That’s coupled closely enough for CAN .

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
electroken:

with a freshman minion holding one end of the pair and a cordless drill on the other

This is really, really tough on the wire.  You end up twisting the the individual wires as well which is really tough on them as the conductors get twisted which puts them under a lot of stress.  That’s why when you take wire twisted like this out of the drill, it wants to twist around and coil weirdly to relieve the stress from the twisting.

“Twisted” wire is really “braided” as @SLAB-Mr.Thomas mentioned.  It’s not even a “purist” thing; it’s the right thing and drill twisting is the wrong way to do it.  The braiding, which doesn’t twist the individual conductors, is why commercially twisted wire comes off the roll so nicely.

We had a whole discussion go down this rabbit hole a few years back culminating in 3D Printable Wire Twisting Tool
